thread.title: Connor Cook is Michigan State's new career leader in wins
thread.title_full: Connor Cook is Michigan State's new career leader in wins

author: freep.com
title: Connor Cook is Michigan State's new career leader in wins
text:
MORE It’s not always pretty with Connor Cook.
The Spartans’ senior quarterback hasn’t thrown for 250 yards in a game yet this season and has thrown for less than 200 passing yards in three of MSU’s five games.
But head coach Mark Dantonio said he doesn’t measure quarterbacks by passing yards or touchdowns. The statistic that matters to him is the one Cook now has more of than any quarterback in program history: wins.
“Quarterbacks are here to win. They’re not here for statistics,” Dantonio said. “It’s great vindication for a quarterback, but it’s also a program thing for our entire program. What it means is that this program has won at an unparalleled level for a number of years.”
No. 2 MSU (5-0 overall, 1-0 Big Ten) built an early 21-0 lead today, then held on late to secure a 24-21 victory against Purdue (1-4, 0-1) in the Spartans’ 100th homecoming. The victory was Cook’s 28th as the Spartans’ starting quarterback, passing former teammate Kirk Cousins for most in program history.
“It’s a great accomplishment and it means a lot, but a lot of the credit goes to being on a team with a great defense,” Cook said. “If you’re not playing your best game, they can make you look better.”
It wasn’t a flashy game for Cook, who completed 13 of 19 passes for 139 yards and a touchdown and leaned heavily on his running game in the second half behind conservative play calling.
He completed only 3 of 7 passes for 11 yards in the second half, but ran five times for 48 yards, including a 22-yard run to put the Spartans in scoring range.
“The weather and stuff made me not trust in my arm as much,” Cook said of a rainy day. “Finally, I kind of, you know, got out of my shell today and rushed a little bit.”
Freshman running back LJ Scott ran for a career-high 146 yards and two touchdowns, but said it was Cook’s running ability which changed the game.
“When he’s a threat as a ball carrier, it makes our offense tougher to defend,” Scott said. “He stepped up and did whatever he had to do today to win the game. … Connor made some big-time throws, too. He’s the man.”
